newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland's Handlowy expects eurobond to help IPO.
newsitem.headline: Poland's Handlowy expects eurobond to help IPO.

text.p: Poland's Bank Handlowy expects its successful $200 million eurobond placement will help whet the appetite of equity investors for its public offering due in late May and June, the bank's chief executive said on Thursday.

Cezary Stypulkowski said after an official signing of the eurobond deal with its manager JP Morgan, that high demand, which made it increase the original offer by $50 million, and an attractive price bode well for the bank's share offer.
"This issue is very much in preparation for our initial public offering," Stypulkowski said. @
"We expect that with this (eurobond) issue we will be able to influence the way Bank Handlowy is perceived by investors on international markets," he added.
He said that Bank Handlowy, which placed the $200 million 3-year bond at 60 bp above U.S. treasuries, got the best price of all institutional issuers from Eastern and Central Europe.

Poland is offering up to 15 percent of Handlowy's shares in public subscription to domestic retail investors, 30 percent to domestic and foreign institutions and up to 42.86 percent to a selected group of international financial institutions. @
Last year Handlowy entered international capital markets with a $100 million eurobond, which then sold at 88 bp above U.S. treasuries.
Stypulkowski said that Handlowy's privatisation was perceived by investors as a very positive development and should not adversely influence the bank's rating, now at the same level as Poland's.
Bank Handlowy last year was awarded a Baa3 rating from Moody's, the same as Poland's sovereign debt. Stypulkowski said he hoped Poland's upgrade would allow to improve also Handlowy's rating. @
